title-group.article-title: The Impact of Market Uncertainty on Municipal Bond Underwriter Spread

abstract.p: This study provides empirical documentation of the effect of market uncertainty on municipal bond underwriter spreads. The evidence suggests that underwriter spreads on both competitive and negotiated issues increase during periods of market uncertainty. Such behavior is consistent with the high carrying cost and inventory risk exposure faced by investment bankers during high and volatile interest rate periods. The findings also reveal that the spreads on negotiated bonds increase at a faster rate than spreads on competitive issues during periods of market instability. This implies that either the value of the origination services provided by negotiated underwriters increases as markets deteriorate and/or the lack of competition actually strengthens the monopolistic position of negotiated underwriters during such periods. When the data were partitioned into "regional" and "national" issuers, the results for the regional bond sample were similar to those discussed above. For bonds sold nationally, negotiated sales had lower spreads than similar competitive sales that receive one bid; after one bid, there was no difference between the spreads for the two methods of sale. Furthermore, the spreads on competitive and negotiated nationally sold bond issues were equally sensitive to changes in market uncertainty. Thus, large well-known municipalities can sell their bonds by negotiation and receive an underwriter spread that is at least equal to a competitive sale, and during unstable market periods they may be able to reduce spreads even more through a negotiated deal.
